prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1527 CO32
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim at the CO(3-2) detection redshifted in band 3 with the ALMA C36-1 compact array.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select the high spectra resolution mode (FDM) used in dual polarization. We define 4 basebands, two inside each sidebands (LSB and USB). One baseband is optimized for the CO(3-2) line detection. It is centered on 91.9181 GHz, the redshifted CO(3-2) line (z=2.762). We choose the spectral resolution of 7.813 MHz after Hanning smoothing and using a spectral averaging of 16, it results in 25.48 km/s channels. At this spectral resolution, we have a good sampling in almost 8 spectral resolution elements of our expected FWHM = 200 km/s CO(3-2) line. The remaining 3 basebands are used for the continuum, where we choose the lowest spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz to get the largest effective bandwidth of 1.875 GHz per baseband.

We are interested in determining the molecular gas content of main sequence, star-forming galaxies at z~3. The detection of CO lines in such high-redshift galaxies is already challenging, and therefore we do not want to resolve our targets. The ALMA most compact configuration C36-1 provides the highest sensitivity, which is ideal for detection studies. Our targets are relatively compact, often smaller than the requested angular resolution, therefore the requested largest angular scale is not relevant in this proposal.

The expected molecular gas mass of the selected z=2.762 target for ALMA observations is estimated from its measured stellar mass (as derived from photometry and SED fitting) and the conservative molecular gas fraction mean, fmolgas = 0.51, in the z_3.0=[2.7,3.2] redshift bin (see Table 1 and Fig.1, left panel found in the Science Justification pdf file). This molecular gas mass is then converted into the CO(3-2) luminosity and the CO(3-2) integrated flux by assuming a Galactic CO-H2 conversion factor alpha = 4.36 Msun/(K km/s pc^2) and the luminosity correction factor r3,1 = L'CO(1-0)/L'CO(3-2) = 0.57 for the CO(3-2) line (Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015). The CO(3-2) transition is the lowest J>1 rotationally excited CO transition redshifted in the ALMA bands. It falls in the ALMA band 3 at 91.9181 GHz. We get: L'CO(3-2) = 2e+10 K km/s pc^2 and for the integrated flux 0.51 Jy km/s. We then assume a FWHM of 200 km/s for the CO(3-2) line, according to the previous CO(3-2) detections in main sequence, star-forming galaxies at z~3 found in the literature. To get a reliable detection of such a line with a peak flux of 2.57 mJy, a 5 sigma detection over four spectral resolution elements is necessary. This determines the requested rms of 0.51 mJy in 50 km/s channels.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1226 CO32
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim at the CO(3-2) detection redshifted in band 3 with the ALMA C36-1 compact array.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select the high spectra resolution mode (FDM) used in dual polarization. We define 4 basebands, two inside each sidebands (LSB and USB). One baseband is optimized for the CO(3-2) line detection. It is centered on 88.1009 GHz, the redshifted CO(3-2) line (z=2.925). We choose the spectral resolution of 7.813 MHz after Hanning smoothing and using a spectral averaging of 16, it results in 26.58 km/s channels. At this spectral resolution, we have a good sampling in 7 spectral resolution elements of our expected FWHM = 200 km/s CO(3-2) line. The remaining 3 basebands are used for the continuum, where we choose the lowest spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz to get the largest effective bandwidth of 1.875 GHz per baseband.

We are interested in determining the molecular gas content of main sequence, star-forming galaxies at z~3. The detection of CO lines in such high-redshift galaxies is already challenging, and therefore we do not want to resolve our targets. The ALMA most compact configuration C36-1 provides the highest sensitivity, which is ideal for detection studies. Our targets are relatively compact, often smaller than the requested angular resolution, therefore the requested largest angular scale is not relevant in this proposal.

The expected molecular gas mass of the selected z=2.925 target for ALMA observations is estimated from its measured stellar mass (as derived from photometry and SED fitting) and the conservative molecular gas fraction mean, fmolgas = 0.51, in the z_3.0=[2.7,3.2] redshift bin (see Table 1 and Fig.1, left panel found in the Science Justification pdf file). This molecular gas mass is then converted into the CO(3-2) luminosity and the CO(3-2) integrated flux by assuming a Galactic CO-H2 conversion factor alpha = 4.36 Msun/(K km/s pc^2) and the luminosity correction factor r3,1 = L'CO(1-0)/L'CO(3-2) = 0.57 for the CO(3-2) line (Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. 2015). The CO(3-2) transition is the lowest J>1 rotationally excited CO transition redshifted in the ALMA bands. It falls in the ALMA band 3 at 88.1009 GHz. We get: L'CO(3-2) = 2.9e+10 K km/s pc^2 and for the integrated flux 0.65 Jy km/s. We then assume a FWHM of 200 km/s for the CO(3-2) line, according to the previous CO(3-2) detections in main sequence, star-forming galaxies at z~3 found in the literature. To get a reliable detection of such a line with a peak flux of 3.26 mJy, a 5 sigma detection over four spectral resolution elements is necessary. This determines the requested rms of 0.65 mJy in 50 km/s channels.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: A2895-arc1 CO43
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim at the CO(4-3) detection redshifted in band 3 with the ALMA C36-1 compact array.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select the high spectra resolution mode (FDM) used in dual polarization. We define 4 basebands, two inside each sidebands (LSB and USB). One baseband is optimized for the CO(4-3) line detection. It is centered on 104.7820 GHz, the redshifted CO(4-3) line (z=3.40). We choose the spectral resolution of 7.813 MHz after Hanning smoothing and using a spectral averaging of 16, it results in 22.35 km/s channels. At this spectral resolution, we have a good sampling in almost 9 spectral resolution elements of our expected FWHM = 200 km/s CO(4-3) line. The remaining 3 basebands are used for the continuum, where we choose the lowest spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz to get the largest effective bandwidth of 1.875 GHz per baseband.

We are interested in determining the molecular gas content of main sequence, star-forming galaxies at z~3. The detection of CO lines in such high-redshift galaxies is already challenging, and therefore we do not want to resolve our targets. The ALMA most compact configuration C36-1 provides the highest sensitivity, which is ideal for detection studies. Our targets are relatively compact, often smaller than the requested angular resolution, therefore the requested largest angular scale is not relevant in this proposal.

The expected molecular gas mass of the selected z=3.40 target for ALMA observations is estimated from its measured stellar mass (as derived from photometry and SED fitting) and the conservative molecular gas fraction mean, fmolgas = 0.51, in the z_3.0=[2.7,3.2] redshift bin (see Table 1 and Fig.1, left panel found in the Science Justification pdf file). This molecular gas mass is then converted into the CO(4-3) luminosity and the CO(4-3) integrated flux by assuming a Galactic CO-H2 conversion factor alpha = 4.36 Msun/(K km/s pc^2) and the luminosity correction factor r4,1 = L'CO(1-0)/L'CO(4-3) = 0.5 for the CO(4-3) line. The CO(4-3) transition is the lowest J>1 rotationally excited CO transition redshifted in the ALMA bands. It falls in the ALMA band 3 at 104.7820 GHz. We get: L'CO(4-3) = 6.7e+9 K km/s pc^2 and for the integrated flux 0.21 Jy km/s. We then assume a FWHM of 200 km/s for the CO(4-3) line. To get a reliable detection of such a line with a peak flux of 1.06 mJy, a 5 sigma detection over four spectral resolution elements is necessary. This determines the requested rms of 0.21 mJy in 50 km/s channels.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SMACSJ2031 CO43
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim at the CO(4-3) detection redshifted in band 3 with the ALMA C36-1 compact array.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select the high spectra resolution mode (FDM) used in dual polarization. We define 4 basebands, two inside each sidebands (LSB and USB). One baseband is optimized for the CO(4-3) line detection. It is centered on 102.2876 GHz, the redshifted CO(4-3) line (z=3.5073). We choose the spectral resolution of 7.813 MHz after Hanning smoothing and using a spectral averaging of 16, it results in 22.90 km/s channels. At this spectral resolution, we have a good sampling in almost 9 spectral resolution elements of our expected FWHM = 200 km/s CO(4-3) line. The remaining 3 basebands are used for the continuum, where we choose the lowest spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz to get the largest effective bandwidth of 1.875 GHz per baseband.

We are interested in determining the molecular gas content of main sequence, star-forming galaxies at z~3. The ALMA most compact configuration C36-1 provides the highest sensitivity, which is ideal for detection studies. Our targets are relatively compact, often smaller than the requested angular resolution, therefore the requested largest angular scale is not relevant in this proposal.

The expected molecular gas mass of the selected z=3.5073 target for ALMA observations is estimated from its measured stellar mass (as derived from photometry and SED fitting) and the conservative molecular gas fraction mean, fmolgas = 0.51, in the z_3.0=[2.7,3.2] redshift bin (see Table 1 and Fig.1, left panel found in the Science Justification pdf file). This molecular gas mass is then converted into the CO(4-3) luminosity and the CO(4-3) integrated flux by assuming a Galactic CO-H2 conversion factor alpha = 4.36 Msun/(K km/s pc^2) and the luminosity correction factor r4,1 = L'CO(1-0)/L'CO(4-3) = 0.5 for the CO(4-3) line. The CO(4-3) transition is the lowest J>1 rotationally excited CO transition redshifted in the ALMA bands. It falls in the ALMA band 3 at 102.2876 GHz. We get: L'CO(4-3) = 7.7e+9 K km/s pc^2 and for the integrated flux 0.23 Jy km/s. We then assume a FWHM of 200 km/s for the CO(4-3) line. To get a reliable detection of such a line with a peak flux of 1.16 mJy, a 5 sigma detection over four spectral resolution elements is necessary. This determines the requested rms of 0.23 mJy in 50 km/s channels.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AS1063-arc5.1 CO43
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim at the CO(4-3) detection redshifted in band 3 with the ALMA C36-1 compact array.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select the high spectra resolution mode (FDM) used in dual polarization. We define 4 basebands, two inside each sidebands (LSB and USB). One baseband is optimized for the CO(4-3) line detection. It is centered on 112.0118 GHz, the redshifted CO(4-3) line (z=3.116). We choose the spectral resolution of 7.813 MHz after Hanning smoothing and using a spectral averaging of 16, it results in 20.91 km/s channels. At this spectral resolution, we have a good sampling in 9 spectral resolution elements of our expected FWHM = 200 km/s CO(4-3) line. The remaining 3 basebands are used for the continuum, where we choose the lowest spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz to get the largest effective bandwidth of 1.875 GHz per baseband.

We are interested in determining the molecular gas content of main sequence, star-forming galaxies at z~3. The detection of CO lines in such high-redshift galaxies is already challenging, and therefore we do not want to resolve our targets. The ALMA most compact configuration C36-1 provides the highest sensitivity, which is ideal for detection studies. Our targets are relatively compact, often smaller than the requested angular resolution, therefore the requested largest angular scale is not relevant in this proposal.

The expected molecular gas mass of the selected z=3.116 target for ALMA observations is estimated from its measured stellar mass (as derived from photometry and SED fitting) and the conservative molecular gas fraction mean, fmolgas = 0.51, in the z_3.0=[2.7,3.2] redshift bin (see Table 1 and Fig.1, left panel found in the Science Justification pdf file). This molecular gas mass is then converted into the CO(4-3) luminosity and the CO(4-3) integrated flux by assuming a Galactic CO-H2 conversion factor alpha = 4.36 Msun/(K km/s pc^2) and the luminosity correction factor r4,1 = L'CO(1-0)/L'CO(4-3) = 0.5 for the CO(4-3) line. The CO(4-3) transition is the lowest J>1 rotationally excited CO transition redshifted in the ALMA bands. It falls in the ALMA band 3 at 112.0118 GHz. We get: L'CO(4-3) = 7.5e+9 K km/s pc^2 and for the integrated flux 0.27 Jy km/s. We then assume a FWHM of 200 km/s for the CO(4-3) line. To get a reliable detection of such a line with a peak flux of 1.36 mJy, a 5 sigma detection over four spectral resolution elements is necessary. This determines the requested rms of 0.27 mJy in 50 km/s channels.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The cosmic evolution of the molecular gas fraction (fmolgas) with Hubble time is predicted by models. Measurements of molecular gas have recently become feasible in normal star-forming galaxies at z~0.5-3, which lie on the main sequence and contribute ~90% to the cosmic SFR density. They show a clear fmolgas rise between z=0 and z~2, followed by a very mild, quasi flat increase towards high redshifts, while a steady fmolgas increase with reshift is expected. The statistics at z>2.5, however, is very poor, with only 5 fmolgas measurements available. The molecular gas measure in main sequence galaxies at z~3 is challenging and is one of the ALMA science drivers. We propose to double the number of fmolgas measurements at z~3, before the full ALMA completion, with the help of gravitational lensing. We have identified 5 strongly-lensed, main sequence galaxies at z=[2.7,3.5] with accessible fmolgas within a reasonable observing time from CO lines redshifted in band 3. They will yield a more reliable fmolgas estimate at z~3 and constrain the evolutionary trend of fmolgas with cosmic time by disentangling between a steady rise, a flattening beyond z>2, or a decline towards high redshifts.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
